CAMPUS NOTES
Turnbull Lecture

tinue on Tuesday, March 8th,
when Wolfgang Clemen, Professor of English at the University
of Munich, will speak on "The
Spirits in Shelley's Poetry." Professor Clemen will speak at 4
p.m. In the auditorium of the
new classroom building.

The Johns Hopkins University
has announced that the Turnbull
Lecture to be given on Friday,
February 18th by Jorge Guillen
has been postponed until April.
Guillen, a Spanish poet, was to
have spoken on "A Portrait of
Pedro Salinas."
Chamber Orchestra
An announcement will be
The New Chamber Orchestra,
made as soon as a new date has under Musical Director Angelo
been set.
Gatto, is scheduled to appear in
The Turnbull series will con- concert on Sunday, March 13 at

8:30 p. m. in Shriver Hall.
This will be the group's second Hopkins appearance.
In
January, the Orchestra performed with cellist Paul Olefsky
to capacity crowds in Shriver
Hall. At present, the concert intends to feature the group's own
chorus and soloists.
Tickets may be purchased from
the Office of Special Events, in
the basement of Shriver Hall, at
$1.00 for students and $1.50 for
the public.

Mixer Off—Movie On
The "Y" has cancelled the
mixer scheduled for tonight because of the Slalom Ball. Despite the conflict, the regularly
scheduled film, The Bridge on
the River Kwai, will be shown.

New President
Wilbert E. Locklin will be inaugurated as ninth president of
Springfield College on Saturday,
April 30, it has been announced

by Norman C. Keith, Chairman
of the Springfield Board at
Trustees.
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower will
deliver the address to the negw
president. He will also be the
recipient of an honorary degree
from Springfield College.
President Locklin, 45, form..
erly assistant to Dr. Eisenhower
at Hopkins, and also vice president of the John Hopkins Fund,
took office last October 1.

If nothing interests you as much
as research and development...
consider the advantages of a career
in the laboratories of the
David Taylor Model Basin
The David Taylor Model Basin, one of the oldest government
laboratories, has grown steadily in size and responsibility and
is now concerned with design concepts for aircraft and
missiles,as well as with surface ships and submarines. Its five
major laboratories conduct basic, applied, and developmental
research in these fields:
HYDRODYNAMICS—Hydrofoilcraft,interface vehicles, novel
ship types, fluid dynamics, high-speed phenomena.
AERODYNAMICS—Aircushion vehicles, weapon release
problems, V/STOL aircraft, aircraft performance.
STRUCTURAL MECHANICS—Submarine and surface ship
structures, effects of underwater and surface explosions, ship
and personnel protection, deep-sea research vehicles.
APPLIED MATHEMATICS—Computer-aided ship and system design, automated data processing, numerical techniques,
management data analysis.
ACOUSTICS AND VIBRATION—Radiated, near-field, self
and hydrodynamic noise, countermeasures, silencing devices,
noise transmission.
An engineering or scientific career at the David Taylor Model
Basin offers you many advantages:
1. Because of the mission of the Model Basin, you can be sure
that you will be engaged in research, development, test and
evaluation not as a bystander, but as an active and increasingly
important participant. Whatever your discipline, you will have
the opportunity to apply it to one of the important projects in
which the Model Basin is engaged.
2. You will have the satisfaction and excitement of working
on projects that advance the state of the art and are of national
and international importance.
3. Working with you will be men whose engineering and scientific achievements have earned them wide reputations in
their fields. Your contact with them will be of immeasurable
value in your own development as a professional engineer or
scientist.
4. You will work in a campus-like environment with 186 acres
of laboratories and supporting facilities with millions of dollars
worth of equipment. For instance, the Hydromechanics Lab-

oratory has a Towing Basin 3/5 of a mile long, 50 feet wide,
and 20 feet deep; a Maneuvering Basin that covers 5 acres.
The Applied Mathematics Laboratory uses four high-speed
digital computers to solve engineering and logistic problems.
The ultra-high-speed UNIVAC LARC performs 250,000 computations per second. The Aerodynamics Laboratory is equipped
with nine wind tunnels, subsonic, transonic, supersonic, hypersonic, for the testing of aircraft, missile and airborne component models. Ten pressure tanks, and tensile and compressive load testing machines are among the devices used by the
Structural Mechanics Laboratory in research on hull structures
for ships, deep-diving submarines and deep-sea research
vehicles. Mechanical generators in the Acoustics and Vibration Laboratory can produce known forces in structures ranging from small items of machinery to complete ships.
5. The management of the Model Basin is interested in your
professional development. It provides you with the opportunity to receive financial assistance and time(up to 8 hours a
week)to attend classes at one of the six major universities in
the immediate area, which offer courses in virtually every
field. In addition, a number of graduate courses are conducted
at the Model Basin. Under a new program, several employees
34 -time advanced academic study
are now engaged in full or /
and receiving full salary as well as all their expenses.
6. At the David Taylor Model Basin, you can reach the
$10,000 to $12,000 level within four years. In addition, as a
Civil Service employee, you get generous vacations and sick
leave, inexpensive life and health insurance, and enjoy the
benefits of an unusually liberal retirement program.
7. Within minutes of the Model Basin are the suburbs of
Maryland and Virginia offering excellent living conditions, unusual recreational facilities, and some of the best public school
systems in the country. Because the Washington area is a center for scientific research as well as for government, it boasts a
large concentration of people of intellectual and cultural attainments. Washingtor4 D. C. with its museums, art galleries,
libraries and points of historical interest is just 12 miles from
the Model Basin.
For more information about the David Taylor Model Basin and
the opportunity it offers you, see the interviewer who visits
your campus or write directly to Mr. S. DiMaria, Head, Office
of Civilian Personnel.

K's for COSE
The annual Spring Calendar, distributed this past
week, discloses that Homewood will host a variety of
lecturers and speakers this semester. The list is wide—
ranging from OAS Secretary General Jose Mora, through
such luminaries as.Joseph Alsop, to Dave Brubeek. It
is deep, too-23 guest speakers are planned. Two observations are in order.
One, Hopkins can he proud that notice of the appearance of Bayard Bustin passed virtually without
comment. When Bustin was scheduled to speak at the
University of Maryland, furor from diverse elements
almost cancelled the program. Homewood has again
proven that it is mature enough to endure, without adverse commentary, the appearance of one whose beliefs may not be universally held.
Two, while sponsorship of the various speakers
lies with a nuniber of campus organizations—from Phi
Beta Kappa to Levering Hall--credit for the mammoth
job of organization and coordinates rests with the University's Committee on Special Events. Public Relations
men invariably resent acknowledgement in the press of
their efforts, so kudos for the execution of a fine program go to COSE chairman J.S. and able assistants T.K.
and G.S.W.

Booksfore, Con't.
At this semiannual juncture, the Bookstore again
rears its .... head, Hopefully, expansion will alleviate
at least the inefficiency of purchasing books and supplies. The later, especially, oftimes seem overpriced.
One wonders, amidst all the chatter, whether the students
are doing all the stealing. ..

"What else are you faking?"
Spring 1966 course offerings seem too few. This
might explain why a random re-gistration day sampling
showed, for instance, Dr. Rothstein's New Nations in
World Affairs over the 30 mark at midday, or Dr.
Ambrose's War in the Modern World pushing 90 in
enrollment as registration neared closing.
It is not enough to say that such courses as these
excite students' interests so much that many went to
take them; a good proportion of those enrolled are
simply looking for something that "sounds good". And
not that much sounds good; there really isn't that
much to begin with. Also, if a course is not listed and
described in the undergraduate catalogue, then it should
be adequately described in the course list issued by
the registrar's office just prior to semester break.

Way to Hop
We wholeheartedly commend Dr. Eisenhower for
his announcement that, beginning this autumn, the University housing Bureau will refuse to list private and
commercial landlords who do not pledge to accept applications from Hopkins persons without regard to race,
color or national origin.

An Explanation
Sharp-eyed readers will notice that this issue's
masthead lists new editors-in-chief. The change is not
permanent; editors Freedman and Desehanel should be
back at their typewriters within several weeks. Meanwhile, the interim editors will endeavor to maintain
high standards. You can't please all of the people all
of the time...

To the Editor:
As long as the News-Letter is
supported entirely by advertising and subscriptions, I feel that
Mr. Mindel was grossly unjustified in his attack on the editors.
If the News-Letter was subsidized by the administration,
for instance, I am sure that the
editors would feel it their duty
to report the news in as fair
and unbiased a manner as possible. Certainly if the NewsLetter could not pay its own
way the editors would feel obligated to cease using it as a
medium to air their own vendettas and the incomprehensible
journalistic gems of their staff.
The fact is, the News-Letter
receives more money from the
university than does any other
student activity. The sum would

undoubtedly be greater were it
not for the parents of freshmen
who are induced to subscribe to
the paper before' the freshmen
ever reach this campus. Just how
many copies would the NewsLetter sell to the students if the
cost were ten cents? two cents?
Or even two for a penny?
Without faculty support the
News-Letter would fold; the
Hopkins community would not
suffer. I can think of no better
way to waste the limited activity money available, outside
overt graft, than to relegate it
to the group that puts the biggest practical joke of the year
over on the students, the administration, and the university
every Friday.

ce
the workers. The editors coin.
plain bitterly of administration
intervention and threaten to
"leak" news of such intervention out to the news services.
The administration should give
the News-Letter independence,
financial as well as editorial. if
the News-Letter is worthwhile It
will survive; if not it will die
quickly. I'll give ten to one on
the latter.
Yours truly,
Alexander Kuehl

ROOMMATES:THEIR CAUSE AND CURE
Itou'd think that with all the progress we have made in
the education game, somebody would have found a cure
for roommates by now. But no. Roommates remain as big
problem today as they were when Ethan Mather foundedl
the first American college.
(Contrary to popular belief, Harvard was not the first.'
Mr. Mather started his institution some 100 years earlier.
And quite an institution it was,let me tell you! Mr.Mather
built schools of liberal arts, tine arts, dentistry and tanning. He built a lacrosse stadium that seated 200,000.
Everywhere on campus was emblazoned the stirring Latin
rotto CAVE MUSS1 —"Watch out for moose." The stu•
dent union contained a bowling alley, a weighing mat,
Chine, and a sixteen-chair barber shop.)
(It was this last feature—the barber shop—that, alas,l,
brought Mr. Mather's college to an early end. The student'
body, being drawn chiefly from the nearby countryside,
was composed almost entirely of Pequot and Iroquois Indiens who, alas, had no need of a barber shop. They,1
braided the hair on top of their heads,and as for the hair on
their faces, they had none. The barber, Tremblatt Follicle
by name,grew so depressed staring day after day at 16emp•
ty chairs that one day his mind gave way.Seizing his vibrator, he ran outside and shook the entire campus till it crumbled to dust. This later became known as Pickett's Charge.)'
But I digress. We were exploring ways for you and yourl
roommate to stop hating each other. This is admittedly,
difficult but not impossible if you will both bend a bit,
give a little.
I remember, for example, my own college days (Berlits
'08). My roommate was, I think you will allow, even less
agreeable than most. He was a Tibetan named Ringading
whose native customs, while indisputably colorful, were
not entirely endearing. Mark you, I didn't mind so much
the gong he struck on the hour or the string of firecrackers he set off on the half hour. I didn't even mind that he
singed chicken feathers every dusk and daybreak. What jj
did mind was that he singed them in my hat.

Theater Critic
Talks Criticism

INTRAMURAL SPORTS 11
Compiled By
JED P. LUCHOW

Mr. Richard Gilman, drama
critic for Newsweek Magazine,
will deliver the Amos Taylor, Jr.,
Memorial Lecture, Sunday, February 27, at 8:30 p.m. Formerly
drama critic and literary editor
of Commonweal, Mr. Gilman will
speak on "Criticism in the
American Theatre."
The Shriver Hall appearance
is the second of the season's
Amos Taylor, Jr. programs, under the auspices of Theatre
Hopkins.
Mr.. Gilman is Visiting Lecturer in English at Columbia
University and was a lecturer
of modern American drama in
the Summer of 1965 Salzburg
Seminar in American Studies.
A past recipient of Rockefeller and Guggenheim grants, Mr.
Gilman is currently writing a
book, Contemporary American
Culture, to be published by Random House next year.
Tickets for Mr. Gilman's address may be purchased at the
door or by contacting the Johns
Hopkins Public Relations Office.

BY MARSHALL PAUL

If anybody but Hopkins were a place ahead of his team
the Mason-Dixon Conference standings right now, -University of Baltimore basketball coach Paul Baker would be unhappyEven if the fourth place Jays were to finish number one
or two, their record doesn't count. Besides that, Hopkins is
ineligible for the Mason-Dixon post-season playoffs no matter
what it finishes. That means the team right behind it would
get its playoff spot if Hopkins qualified.
The whole problem is that Hopkins is playing in two conferences but has to declare itself as attempting to qualify for
the NCAA small-colitge championship in only one. Ever since
1961, the Jays have chosen to be eligible in the Middle
Atlantic Conference. The winner of that league i7 an automatic
qualifier for the NCAA tourney.
The Jays also compete in the Mason-Dixon Conference.
(This league is divided into two divisions, Northern and
Southern. Four teams, the top two in each bracket, play off
at the end of the season for a pair of NCAA qualifying spots.)
Considering its upset of Loyola, few would say that Hopkins
has played a minor role, but for two reasons it is ineligible
for the playoffs this year.

outing.

just a few seconds longer to pin
Dick Knauer.

with two pins.

Blizzard. "He came within an
inch."

If nothing interests you as much
as research and development...
consider the advantages of a career
in the laboratories of the
David Taylor Model Basin
The David Taylor Model Basin, one of the oldest government
laboratories, has grown steadily in size and responsibility and
is now concerned with design concepts for aircraft and
missiles,as well as with surface ships and submarines. Its five
major laboratories conduct basic, applied, and developmental
research in these fields:
HYDRODYNAMICS—Hydrofoilcraft,interface vehicles, novel
ship types, fluid dynamics, high-speed phenomena.
AERODYNAMICS—Aircushion vehicles, weapon release
problems, V/STOL aircraft, aircraft performance.
STRUCTURAL MECHANICS—Submarine and surface ship
structures, effects of underwater and surface explosions, ship
and personnel protection, deep-sea research vehicles.
APPLIED MATHEMATICS—Computer-aided ship and system design, automated data processing, numerical techniques,
management data analysis.
ACOUSTICS AND VIBRATION—Radiated, near-field, self
and hydrodynamic noise, countermeasures, silencing devices,
noise transmission.
An engineering or scientific career at the David Taylor Model
Basin offers you many advantages:
1. Because of the mission of the Model Basin, you can be sure
that you will be engaged in research, development, test and
evaluation not as a bystander, but as an active and increasingly
important participant. Whatever your discipline, you will have
the opportunity to apply it to one of the important projects in
which the Model Basin is engaged.
2. You will have the satisfaction and excitement of working
on projects that advance the state of the art and are of national
and international importance.
3. Working with you will be men whose engineering and scientific achievements have earned them wide reputations in
their fields. Your contact with them will be of immeasurable
value in your own development as a professional engineer or
scientist.
4. You will work in a campus-like environment with 186 acres
of laboratories and supporting facilities with millions of dollars
worth of equipment. For instance, the Hydromechanics Lab-

oratory has a Towing Basin 3/5 of a mile long, 50 feet wide,
and 20 feet deep; a Maneuvering Basin that covers 5 acres.
The Applied Mathematics Laboratory uses four high-speed
digital computers to solve engineering and logistic problems.
The ultra-high-speed UNIVAC LARC performs 250,000 computations per second. The Aerodynamics Laboratory is equipped
with nine wind tunnels, subsonic, transonic, supersonic, hypersonic, for the testing of aircraft, missile and airborne component models. Ten pressure tanks, and tensile and compressive load testing machines are among the devices used by the
Structural Mechanics Laboratory in research on hull structures
for ships, deep-diving submarines and deep-sea research
vehicles. Mechanical generators in the Acoustics and Vibration Laboratory can produce known forces in structures ranging from small items of machinery to complete ships.
5. The management of the Model Basin is interested in your
professional development. It provides you with the opportunity to receive financial assistance and time(up to 8 hours a
week)to attend classes at one of the six major universities in
the immediate area, which offer courses in virtually every
field. In addition, a number of graduate courses are conducted
at the Model Basin. Under a new program, several employees
34 -time advanced academic study
are now engaged in full or /
and receiving full salary as well as all their expenses.
6. At the David Taylor Model Basin, you can reach the
$10,000 to $12,000 level within four years. In addition, as a
Civil Service employee, you get generous vacations and sick
leave, inexpensive life and health insurance, and enjoy the
benefits of an unusually liberal retirement program.
7. Within minutes of the Model Basin are the suburbs of
Maryland and Virginia offering excellent living conditions, unusual recreational facilities, and some of the best public school
systems in the country. Because the Washington area is a center for scientific research as well as for government, it boasts a
large concentration of people of intellectual and cultural attainments. Washingtor4 D. C. with its museums, art galleries,
libraries and points of historical interest is just 12 miles from
the Model Basin.
For more information about the David Taylor Model Basin and
the opportunity it offers you, see the interviewer who visits
your campus or write directly to Mr. S. DiMaria, Head, Office
of Civilian Personnel.

K's for COSE
The annual Spring Calendar, distributed this past
week, discloses that Homewood will host a variety of
lecturers and speakers this semester. The list is wide—
ranging from OAS Secretary General Jose Mora, through
such luminaries as.Joseph Alsop, to Dave Brubeek. It
is deep, too-23 guest speakers are planned. Two observations are in order.
One, Hopkins can he proud that notice of the appearance of Bayard Bustin passed virtually without
comment. When Bustin was scheduled to speak at the
University of Maryland, furor from diverse elements
almost cancelled the program. Homewood has again
proven that it is mature enough to endure, without adverse commentary, the appearance of one whose beliefs may not be universally held.
Two, while sponsorship of the various speakers
lies with a nuniber of campus organizations—from Phi
Beta Kappa to Levering Hall--credit for the mammoth
job of organization and coordinates rests with the University's Committee on Special Events. Public Relations
men invariably resent acknowledgement in the press of
their efforts, so kudos for the execution of a fine program go to COSE chairman J.S. and able assistants T.K.
and G.S.W.

Booksfore, Con't.
At this semiannual juncture, the Bookstore again
rears its .... head, Hopefully, expansion will alleviate
at least the inefficiency of purchasing books and supplies. The later, especially, oftimes seem overpriced.
One wonders, amidst all the chatter, whether the students
are doing all the stealing. ..

"What else are you faking?"
Spring 1966 course offerings seem too few. This
might explain why a random re-gistration day sampling
showed, for instance, Dr. Rothstein's New Nations in
World Affairs over the 30 mark at midday, or Dr.
Ambrose's War in the Modern World pushing 90 in
enrollment as registration neared closing.
It is not enough to say that such courses as these
excite students' interests so much that many went to
take them; a good proportion of those enrolled are
simply looking for something that "sounds good". And
not that much sounds good; there really isn't that
much to begin with. Also, if a course is not listed and
described in the undergraduate catalogue, then it should
be adequately described in the course list issued by
the registrar's office just prior to semester break.

Way to Hop
We wholeheartedly commend Dr. Eisenhower for
his announcement that, beginning this autumn, the University housing Bureau will refuse to list private and
commercial landlords who do not pledge to accept applications from Hopkins persons without regard to race,
color or national origin.

masthead lists new editors-in-chief. The change is not
permanent; editors Freedman and Desehanel should be
back at their typewriters within several weeks. Meanwhile, the interim editors will endeavor to maintain
high standards. You can't please all of the people all
of the time...

To the Editor:
As long as the News-Letter is
supported entirely by advertising and subscriptions, I feel that
Mr. Mindel was grossly unjustified in his attack on the editors.
If the News-Letter was subsidized by the administration,
for instance, I am sure that the
editors would feel it their duty
to report the news in as fair
and unbiased a manner as possible. Certainly if the NewsLetter could not pay its own
way the editors would feel obligated to cease using it as a
medium to air their own vendettas and the incomprehensible
journalistic gems of their staff.
The fact is, the News-Letter
receives more money from the
university than does any other
student activity. The sum would

undoubtedly be greater were it
not for the parents of freshmen
who are induced to subscribe to
the paper before' the freshmen
ever reach this campus. Just how
many copies would the NewsLetter sell to the students if the
cost were ten cents? two cents?
Or even two for a penny?
Without faculty support the
News-Letter would fold; the
Hopkins community would not
suffer. I can think of no better
way to waste the limited activity money available, outside
overt graft, than to relegate it
to the group that puts the biggest practical joke of the year
over on the students, the administration, and the university
every Friday.

ce
the workers. The editors coin.
plain bitterly of administration
intervention and threaten to
"leak" news of such intervention out to the news services.
The administration should give
the News-Letter independence,
financial as well as editorial. if
the News-Letter is worthwhile It
will survive; if not it will die
quickly. I'll give ten to one on
the latter.
Yours truly,
Alexander Kuehl

ROOMMATES:THEIR CAUSE AND CURE
Itou'd think that with all the progress we have made in
the education game, somebody would have found a cure
for roommates by now. But no. Roommates remain as big
problem today as they were when Ethan Mather foundedl
the first American college.
(Contrary to popular belief, Harvard was not the first.'
Mr. Mather started his institution some 100 years earlier.
And quite an institution it was,let me tell you! Mr.Mather
built schools of liberal arts, tine arts, dentistry and tanning. He built a lacrosse stadium that seated 200,000.
Everywhere on campus was emblazoned the stirring Latin
rotto CAVE MUSS1 —"Watch out for moose." The stu•
dent union contained a bowling alley, a weighing mat,
Chine, and a sixteen-chair barber shop.)
(It was this last feature—the barber shop—that, alas,l,
brought Mr. Mather's college to an early end. The student'
body, being drawn chiefly from the nearby countryside,
was composed almost entirely of Pequot and Iroquois Indiens who, alas, had no need of a barber shop. They,1
braided the hair on top of their heads,and as for the hair on
their faces, they had none. The barber, Tremblatt Follicle
by name,grew so depressed staring day after day at 16emp•
ty chairs that one day his mind gave way.Seizing his vibrator, he ran outside and shook the entire campus till it crumbled to dust. This later became known as Pickett's Charge.)'
But I digress. We were exploring ways for you and yourl
roommate to stop hating each other. This is admittedly,
difficult but not impossible if you will both bend a bit,
give a little.
I remember, for example, my own college days (Berlits
'08). My roommate was, I think you will allow, even less
agreeable than most. He was a Tibetan named Ringading
whose native customs, while indisputably colorful, were
not entirely endearing. Mark you, I didn't mind so much
the gong he struck on the hour or the string of firecrackers he set off on the half hour. I didn't even mind that he
singed chicken feathers every dusk and daybreak. What jj
did mind was that he singed them in my hat.

Mr. Richard Gilman, drama

The Shriver Hall appearance
is the second of the season's

Hopkins.
Mr.. Gilman is Visiting Lecturer in English at Columbia
University and was a lecturer

Gilman is currently writing a
book, Contemporary American
Culture, to be published by Random House next year.

door or by contacting the Johns
Hopkins Public Relations Office.

BY MARSHALL PAUL

If anybody but Hopkins were a place ahead of his team
the Mason-Dixon Conference standings right now, -University of Baltimore basketball coach Paul Baker would be unhappyEven if the fourth place Jays were to finish number one
or two, their record doesn't count. Besides that, Hopkins is
ineligible for the Mason-Dixon post-season playoffs no matter
what it finishes. That means the team right behind it would
get its playoff spot if Hopkins qualified.
The whole problem is that Hopkins is playing in two conferences but has to declare itself as attempting to qualify for
the NCAA small-colitge championship in only one. Ever since
1961, the Jays have chosen to be eligible in the Middle
Atlantic Conference. The winner of that league i7 an automatic
qualifier for the NCAA tourney.
The Jays also compete in the Mason-Dixon Conference.
(This league is divided into two divisions, Northern and
Southern. Four teams, the top two in each bracket, play off
at the end of the season for a pair of NCAA qualifying spots.)
Considering its upset of Loyola, few would say that Hopkins
has played a minor role, but for two reasons it is ineligible
for the playoffs this year.

upset win.
